metadata.titleEn: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (eddy covariance system of Zhangye wetland station, 2023)
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the flux measurements from the Zhangye wetland station eddy covariance system (EC) in the midstream reaches of the Heihe integrated observatory network from January 1 to December 31 in 2023. The site (100.44640° E, 38.97514° N) was located in the Zhangye City in Gansu Province. The elevation is 1460 m. The EC was installed at a height of 5.2 m, and the sampling rate was 10 Hz. The sonic anemometer faced north, and the separation distance between the sonic anemometer and the CO2/H2O gas analyzer (Gill&Li7500A) was 0.25 m.
The raw data acquired at 10 Hz were processed using the Eddypro post-processing software, including the spike detection, lag correction of H2O/CO2 relative to the vertical wind component, sonic virtual temperature correction, coordinate rotation (2-D rotation), corrections for density fluctuation (Webb-Pearman-Leuning correction), and frequency response correction. The EC data were subsequently averaged over 30 min periods. The observation data quality was divided into three classes according to the quality assessment method of stationarity (Δst) and the integral turbulent characteristics test (ITC): class 1-3 (high quality), class 4-6 (good), class 7-8 (poor, better than gap filling data), class9 (rejected). In addition to the above processing steps, the half-hourly flux data were screened in a four-step procedure: (1) data from periods of sensor malfunction were rejected; (2) data collected before or after 1 h of precipitation were rejected; (3) incomplete 30 min data were rejected when the missing data constituted more than 3% of the 30 min raw record. There were 48 records per day, and the missing data were replaced with -6999. Suspicious data were marked in red. 
The released data contained the following variables: data/time, wind direction (Wdir, °), wind speed (Wnd, m/s), the standard deviation of the lateral wind (Std_Uy, m/s), virtual temperature (Tv, ℃), H2O mass density (H2O, g/m3), CO2 mass density (CO2, mg/m3), friction velocity (ustar, m/s), stability (z/L), sensible heat flux (Hs, W/m2), latent heat flux (LE, W/m2), carbon dioxide flux (Fc, mg/ (m2s)), quality assessment of the sensible heat flux (QA_Hs), quality assessment of the latent heat flux (QA_LE), and quality assessment of the carbon flux (QA_Fc). In this dataset, the time of 0:30 corresponds to the average data for the period between 0:00 and 0:30; the data were stored in *.xls format. Detailed information can be found in the suggested references.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information) and Liu et al. (2023).

background: The two-source energy balance (TSEB) model was successfully applied to estimate evaporation (E), transpiration (T), and evapotranspiration (ET) for land covered with vegetation, which has significantly important applications for the terrestrial water cycle and water resource management. One-source evapotranspiration estimation models combine the soil–vegetation components into a single source. However, in real landscape conditions, the surface is heterogeneous and contains a mixture of soil and vegetation having different temperatures and resistance to energy exchange. Therefore, one-source models explicitly cannot estimate the surface evapotranspiration accurately because the effect of.

Shuttleworth and Wallace proposed a typical two-source evapotranspiration estimation model in which the energy partition is assumed to occur in both “the above canopy” and “the under soil” cases. Water vapor and heat meet over the reference height in the interior of the canopy. Moreover, the mixed water vapor and heat can only exit through the top of the canopy; the total heat flux is in addition to the fluxes coming from every surface layer. However, the model is complex, having over five resistances that cannot be accurately calculated. In addition, the model includes required parameters and observations that cannot be readily obtained from operational satellite- and ground-based data; therefore, the range of applications of the model is limited.

The TSEB model has undergone several revisions, improving the estimation of soil and canopy net radiation, the aerodynamic resistance of the soil surface, the fractional vegetation coverage observed at the radiometer view angle, the distribution of regional-scale near-surface air temperature, and soil and canopy component temperatures. Because the TSEB model only requires the surface energy balance model with a single measurement of land surface temperature, the original model and subsequent refinements have been widely used to estimate E and T under a wide variety of vegetation types, vegetation coverage, climates, and spatial scales. However, most studies have only evaluated the total fluxes or ET (soil plus canopy) in comparison with measurements using the Bowen ratio–energy balance system, the eddy covariance (EC) system, or the large aperture scintillometer.

Accurately estimating surface fluxes in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area is a particularly challenging task and is even more difficult when the EC flux measurements of H and LE have an incomplete energy balance closure with respect to the available energy Rn−G0. The previous sensitivity studies found that the TSEB model performance is mainly affected by the uncertainty in surface–air temperature difference. Sometimes, this difference is dominant due to the errors in determining the surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from the surface composite radiometric temperature. In this letter, it is shown that there is an overestimation of the component temperatures compared with the observed composite radiometric. This often leads to the most crucial effect on the TSEB model performance. In addition, another factor is the strong advective environment in this region.
research objective: In this letter, the ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures were used to estimate E, T, and ET, which were better validated with observed ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes, and the ET measurements using an eddy covariance (EC) system.

The objective of this letter is to estimate E, T, and ET using the soil and canopy component temperatures observed via a high-resolution thermal camera as inputs to a series TSEB model and to subsequently better validate E, T, and ET using a combination of the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope technique and EC measurements.
challenges: However, the current composite temperature separation approaches are limited in their effectiveness in arid regions. Moreover, E and T are difficult to measure on the ground.

Errors in the derived component temperature were primarily caused by image classification errors; these classification errors varied with vegetation abundance. The higher uncertainty of H estimation is not only caused by the uncertainty of the TSEB model but also due to the increased uncertainty of the EC system, which is 18% when the mean H is small in the irrigated farmland. Due to image pixel classification errors, soil pixels were counted as vegetation pixels, which produced an overestimation of the canopy temperature under the developing vegetation abundance. Alternatively, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance could have produced the uncertainties in the estimated temperatures. In addition, the estimated uncertainty of the incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy may be another source of Rn estimation errors.
methods: In this letter, the field observations were obtained from the Daman superstation installed in the central oasis, which is a 40-m boundary layer tower located at 100.3722° E, 38.8555° N and at an elevation of 1556 m. The meteorological parameters were measured every 10 min and included air temperature, wind speed, humidity at 5 m over the ground, four-component radiations (measured at 12 m above the ground using a four-component radiometer), and turbulent fluxes (measured at 4.5 m above the ground using an EC system with a sampling frequency of 10 Hz). The soil heat fluxes were measured using three heat plates located 6 cm under the ground. A Fluke Ti55 thermal infrared camera was manually operated on a 25-m-high platform on a boundary layer tower to measure the thermal radiation of the cropland approximately every 120 min; the observations were collected as thermal images from approximately 07:00 to 19:00 China Standard Time (CST) during the daytime. The ground-based measurement data were applied to partition ET into E and T applying the Craig–Gordon model.

To evaluate the TSEB model accurately, the soil heat flux was using the ground measurement. In addition, the soil and canopy sensible heat fluxes were estimated using the series TSEB model, and their latent heat fluxes were calculated while solving the energy balance equations (1) and (2), respectively. The soil and canopy component temperatures were calculated using the images obtained with the thermal camera. To calculate the component temperatures, the visible and NIR images were classified into soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method. Next, the soil and canopy directional brightness temperatures were exacted from the thermal images. Finally, the thermal infrared temperatures were converted to the radiation temperatures using the incoming long-wave radiation from the sky and the soil and canopy emissivities. Next, the simulated radiometric temperatures were validated against the surface radiometric temperatures, which were calculated according to the incoming long-wave radiation observed by the four-component radiometer.
dataset: The experimental area is an artificial oasis that is covered with maize, vegetables, and orchards. Data of day of year (DOY) 170, 173, 176, 192, 195, 231, 252, and 256 were used to determine ET and the ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) to ET during the Multi-Scale Observation Experiment on Evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces, which was part of the Heihe Water Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER-MUSOEXE).
findings: Our results indicated that even under the strongly advective conditions, the TSEB model produced reliable estimates of the E/ET% and T/ET% ratios and of ET. The mean bias and root-mean-square error (RMSE) of E/ET% were 1% and 2%, respectively, and the mean bias and RMSE of T/ET% were −1% and 2%, respectively. In addition, the model exhibited relatively reliable estimates in the latent heat flux, with mean bias and RMSE values of 31 and 61 W·m−2, respectively, compared with the measurements from the EC system. These results demonstrated that a robust soil and vegetation component temperature calculation was crucial for estimating E, T, and ET. Moreover, the separate validation of E/ET% and T/ET% provides a good prospect for TSEB model improvements.

Our results demonstrated that the TSEB model using soil and canopy component radiometric temperatures, which were obtained from a high-precision thermal infrared camera, can be applied in a strongly advection-irrigated agricultural area. Notably, the results illustrated that the latent fluxes of the soil and vegetation components were successfully separated with reasonable accuracy, as assessed using ground-based measurements. The estimated E/ET% and E/ET% values agreed well with the values observed using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes technique during the early, middle, and late growing seasons. In addition, the TSEB model produced reliable estimations of Rn, H, and LE; the mean biases of Rn, H, and LE were −18, 5, and 31 W ·m−2, respectively, and the RMSEs of Rn, H, and LE were 29, 19, and 61 W · m−2, respectively. This finding suggests that given accurate soil and vegetation component temperatures, E and T can be accurately separated from ET using the TSEB model.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in estimating evapotranspiration using models in heterogeneous landscapes?
Example.Answer: A challenge in estimating evapotranspiration using models in heterogeneous landscapes is the difficulty in accurately determining surface soil and vegetation component temperatures. This is due to classification errors in image processing, such as soil pixels being misclassified as vegetation pixels, which can result in overestimation of canopy temperature and affect model performance.

Example.Question: Could you give an example of a dataset that includes long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert systems?
Example.Answer: An example of such a dataset includes long-term observations from 2012 to 2021, comprising energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes, along with auxiliary data on hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters. This dataset is collected from 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations located in the middle and lower reaches of the Heihe River Basin in western China.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of using the eddy covariance system in measuring energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes in arid and semiarid regions?
Definition.Answer: The eddy covariance system is crucial for measuring energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes as it provides half-hourly turbulent flux data essential for understanding the basic characteristics of these exchanges in oasis-desert ecosystems. This method supports the ecological security and sustainable development of oases by offering a quantitative understanding of oasis-desert interactions.

Definition.Question: What challenges are associated with partitioning evapotranspiration into evaporation and transpiration using ground-based measurements in arid regions?
Definition.Answer: Challenges in partitioning evapotranspiration into evaporation and transpiration using ground-based measurements in arid regions include the limited effectiveness of current composite temperature separation approaches and difficulties in accurately measuring these components on the ground. Additionally, errors in image classification and uncertainties in model and measurement systems contribute to the challenges.

Comparison.Question: How does the data collection method using an eddy covariance system compare to the use of a scintillometer in terms of measuring energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Comparison.Answer: The eddy covariance system provides half-hourly turbulent flux data and is part of a suite of observational datasets, which includes energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes. Scintillometers are also used for similar measurements. Both methods are utilized in oasis–desert systems to observe long-term data from artificial and natural settings. The eddy covariance system is highlighted for its detailed flux data, while the scintillometer is mentioned as part of the larger observational setup without specific detail on its individual advantages or drawbacks in comparison.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the challenges of estimating evapotranspiration using the TSEB model differ from the challenges in measuring energy and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas?
Comparison.Answer: The TSEB model faces challenges primarily in estimating surface fluxes due to uncertainties like surface–air temperature differences and the strong advective environment, particularly in irrigated areas. On the other hand, measuring energy and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas involves challenges related to ecological degradation, such as drying rivers and desertification. Both approaches must tackle environmental and model-specific uncertainties, but they differ in focus: TSEB on temperature and model accuracy, and oasis–desert systems on ecological balance and data collection stability.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways do long-term observations of hydrometeorological and flux data enhance the understanding of oasis–desert interactions and support sustainable development?
Interpretation.Answer: Long-term observations provide comprehensive datasets that capture seasonal and interannual variability in energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes. These datasets are essential for understanding the interactions between oasis and desert systems, which is critical for maintaining ecological balance and supporting sustainable development through informed management and policy-making.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in effectively measuring evapotranspiration in arid and semi-arid regions using ground-based methods?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: In arid and semi-arid regions, challenges in measuring evapotranspiration arise due to the heterogeneous landscape that includes a mix of soil and vegetation with different temperatures and resistance to energy exchange, making it difficult for one-source models to accurately estimate surface evapotranspiration. Furthermore, errors in derived component temperatures are primarily caused by image classification errors, which vary with vegetation abundance, and the strong advective environment in these regions adds to the difficulty.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is the balance between oasis and desert systems important for sustainable oasis development in arid and semi-arid regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The balance between oasis and desert systems is important for sustainable oasis development because these systems play a critical role in maintaining ecological stability and agricultural productivity. Understanding the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in these ecosystems is essential to achieving carbon peaking and carbon neutrality, which supports the ecological security and sustainable development of oases. The interaction between these systems influences the overall environmental health and socioeconomic stability in arid and semi-arid regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to maintain long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Long-term observations are critical to understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems. This understanding is essential to achieving the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality, supporting ecological security, and ensuring the sustainable development of oases. Additionally, these observations help recognize oasis–desert interactions, which are significant for protecting the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the intended outcomes of using a high-resolution thermal camera to estimate evaporation, transpiration, and evapotranspiration in agricultural areas?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The use of a high-resolution thermal camera aims to improve the estimation of evaporation, transpiration, and evapotranspiration by providing accurate soil and canopy component temperatures. These measurements are validated with observed ratios using stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes, offering a better understanding of the energy balance in agricultural areas. Achieving reliable estimates in these areas is particularly challenging due to strong advective conditions, and accurate component temperature calculations are crucial for separating evaporation and transpiration effectively.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in processing and quality control of data from eddy covariance systems in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The processing and quality control procedure for eddy covariance system data includes data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing. This involves acquiring half-hourly turbulent flux data, hydrometeorological data, and supplementary vegetation and soil parameters from automatic weather stations, as well as quality control measures to ensure data accuracy and reliability.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the methods used to ensure the accuracy of eddy covariance measurements in highly advective irrigated agricultural areas?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To ensure the accuracy of eddy covariance measurements, the ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures are used alongside the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope technique for validation. Errors are minimized by addressing image classification errors and uncertainties in radiation transmittances. The TSEB model's performance is evaluated by comparing component temperatures with observed composite radiometric temperatures, ensuring robust estimates of energy and water vapor exchanges.

Enablement.Question: How does the use of Eddypro software enable the processing and quality control of eddy covariance data for hydrometeorological studies in wetland environments?
Enablement.Answer: Eddypro software processes the raw 10Hz data into 30-minute flux values, applying steps such as spurious point removal, time delay correction, coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, ultrasonic virtual temperature correction, and density correction. It also evaluates the quality of flux values based on atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity tests, ensuring robust data collection in wetland environments.

Enablement.Question: What conditions and technologies enable the long-term monitoring of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Enablement.Answer: The establishment of a network of land surface flux and meteorological stations, including superstations and ordinary stations, equipped with eddy covariance systems and scintillometers, enable monitoring. These systems, combined with automatic weather stations and supplementary vegetation and soil parameter data, facilitate long-term observations in oasis-desert ecosystems.

Expectation.Question: Why might data collection in oasis–desert ecosystems face unique challenges related to energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange?
Expectation.Answer: Data collection in oasis–desert ecosystems faces challenges due to complex interactions between oasis and desert systems. These areas are critical for maintaining ecological stability and socioeconomic development, yet they are vulnerable to environmental degradation, such as river and lake drying, vegetation degradation, desertification, and dust storms. Long-term observations are essential to quantitatively understand these exchanges and support sustainable development.

Expectation.Question: What are the reasons behind using a high-resolution thermal camera for measuring soil and canopy component temperatures in the field of terrestrial water cycle research?
Expectation.Answer: A high-resolution thermal camera is used to measure soil and canopy component temperatures because it provides precise inputs for models like the two-source energy balance (TSEB) model. This method overcomes limitations of existing composite temperature separation approaches, especially in arid regions, and allows for better validation of evaporation, transpiration, and evapotranspiration estimates. Accurate component temperature measurement helps in separating latent fluxes of soil and vegetation components, which is crucial for model improvements and reliable estimations.

Expectation.Question: Why is the eddy covariance (EC) system commonly employed in studies of evapotranspiration and energy fluxes over heterogeneous land surfaces?
Expectation.Answer: The eddy covariance (EC) system is employed because it provides direct measurements of turbulent fluxes, including latent and sensible heat fluxes, which are vital for estimating evapotranspiration (ET) and energy balance in heterogeneous landscapes. Despite challenges like energy balance closure and uncertainties in strongly advective environments, the EC system remains a standard method for validating models like the TSEB model, especially when combined with additional techniques such as stable isotope observations.

Judgmental.Question: What potential advancements in data collection methods could improve the understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange processes in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Judgmental.Answer: Advancements in data collection methods that could improve understanding of these processes include the development of high-resolution thermal imaging for capturing soil and canopy temperatures, improvements in satellite remote sensing for large-scale observations, and the integration of stable isotope techniques for better validation of evaporation and transpiration estimates. These methods can offer more detailed and accurate datasets, facilitating a deeper understanding of the ecosystem dynamics.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how data collection methods can handle the uncertainties in measuring soil and vegetation component temperatures in arid regions.
Assertion.Answer: The data collection methods in arid regions face challenges such as image classification errors, particularly when vegetation abundance affects the accuracy of component temperature measurements. These uncertainties can be caused by soil pixels being misclassified as vegetation pixels, leading to overestimations of canopy temperatures. Additionally, atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance can introduce uncertainties in temperature estimates.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how data from eddy covariance systems can be processed to ensure quality and accuracy in such diverse environmental conditions.
Assertion.Answer: Data from eddy covariance systems undergo processing steps including data collection, processing, and quality control to ensure accuracy. These systems provide half-hourly turbulent flux data, which are cross-referenced with hydrometeorological data and other auxiliary datasets to validate and refine the measurements, ensuring reliability across diverse environmental conditions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential strategies or methodologies to improve the accuracy of evapotranspiration estimates using two-source energy balance models in heterogeneous landscapes.
Request/Directive.Answer: To improve accuracy, the TSEB model can utilize ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures. The model performance is affected by the uncertainty in surface–air temperature difference, which can be mitigated by accurate component temperature calculation using a high-resolution thermal camera and classifying soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method.
